comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Great photo, the building on the left is one of the few still in existence on the ex GNR network. Also of interest is the very short goods loading bank and siding in the background. This kind of local traffic dwindled in later years. The cabin was regrettably burnt down in the late 1990s, as for the shelter it too disappeared in the 90s.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: I just noticed the headboard on the signal cabin proclaims 'Laytown & Bettystown', though this must have been shortened to just Laytown in later years. I believe the station got it's double name when nearby Bettystown lost its own station in the early years of the railway (1847).

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Judging by the OS map, the siding's about 100 yards. That's about the same as the one in Malahide was as well.

comment.author: 67908005@N02
comment._content: When adding this interesting photo to the Clerestory Coaches (Railways) Group, in line with many other photos already there and as only the picture owner can do this, as requested in the group rules, please kindly geotag, where possible, to identify the location of this picture, for the benefit of many of the world wide members! In the new photostream layout, click on "Add this Photo to your map" on the top of the right hand side of the white space. In case of need refer to Slides 2 & 3 in this set. Many thanks.
